Answer.152543: the reins are like a telephone line keeping the communication between you and them flowing . that s why having a light steady contact with them is important . it helps you feel each other and communicate your intents . they re also helpful as a reinforcing aid you use when other aids don t get the response you re looking for or also for minor adjustments to the horse s body position , direction , and speed . for example , to slow down from a faster gait to a slower one , you d first sit up , sit deeper in the saddle , impede the motion of the horse with your body , and say woah . if that didn t immediately get a response you d continue doing those things as you close your fingers to squeeze the reins like a sponge , increasing pressure on the reins until you get a response . most of the time the horse will respond with very little pressure or almost none at all . if you wanted them to slow down but stay in the same gait you d use what s called a half halt where you maintain forward motion and momentum by keeping your body engaged and keeping your leg on but you ask the horse to collect and come back to you by squeezing your fingers on the outside rein like a gun trigger and saying easy or slow or woah , whatever word you choose to train
